post_text: Mrs. Sussman’s 3rd graders at Paumanok had a great outdoors math lesson where they discussed that, in math, every digit in a number has a place value. Place value can be defined as the value represented by a digit in a number on the basis of its position in the number. They used the alphabet to find the value of their names, by giving each letter a value from 1-26. Math + Chalk + Outside= HAPPY KIDS! #HHHCSD

post_text: The U.S. Department of Agriculture is partnering with organizations in our area to provide free meals through the Summer Food Service Program (SFSP). This program provides free, nutritious meals and snacks to eligible families, to help children get the nutrition they need to learn, play, and grow, throughout the summer months when they are out of school. Local sites include school districts in Brentwood, Bay Shore, Copiague, Amityville and West Babylon. Congratulations to our 24 students who earned the Advanced Placement® (AP®) Capstone Diploma, and our 48 students who earned the AP Seminar and Research Certificate™ during the 2019-20 school year!

The AP Capstone DiplomaTM program allows students to develop critical thinking, research, and presentation skills, both individually and as a team. Students conduct academic research on topics of personal interest in two interdisciplinary courses: AP Seminar and AP Research. To receive the AP Capstone Diploma, students must earn scores of 3 or higher in AP Seminar, AP Research, and on four additional AP Exams. To receive the AP Seminar and Research Certificate, students must earn scores of 3 or higher in AP Seminar and AP Research.

In Half Hollow Hills, students focused their research on a range of topics, including: animal assisted therapy; the influence of genre specific music on teenagers; prenatal health discrepancies between black women and women of other races; the effects of a ketogenic diet on academic performance; and others. #HHHCSD

post_text: Students in Mrs. Brosnan’s Studio In Art Classes didn’t let the “distance between them” stop their lesson on “Tromp L’oeil,” which means to fool or trick the eye! After many videos, synchronous lessons, extra “help” zoom lessons and much hard work, students used skills learned through distance learning to create realistic renderings of candy. With their knowledge of spatial relations, and the use of the grid method, students re-created a candy still life of their choice using color pencil techniques mastered from previous lessons. Bravo to these hard working “Artists.” #HHHCSD

post_text:
Suffolk County Executive Steven Bellone has "challenged” Suffolk County students to share their activity on how they are practicing social distancing on social media. The goal of the “Peer-to-Peer Initiative” is to have student leaders inform their peers on the importance of staying home, while inspiring them to do so in creative ways.

Students should tag Bellone’s social media channels (Facebook: @SteveBellone, Instagram: @countyexecbellone, Twitter: @SteveBellone) and use the hashtags #CovidChallenge and #StayHomeSuffolk, as the county will share several outstanding student activities each week. Please try to keep videos at a one minute maximum, or use photos.

Potential examples include:
· do a responsible physical activity, of any level, that adheres to social distancing
· create and or share a healthy meal
· share a brief reading of their favorite childhood book
· share an art project they are actively working on, and the inspiration behind the work
· share a volunteer project they are working on to assist others during this time

#HHHCSD
